diagrams.description: Chemical engineering emerged in the late 1800s as industries required systematic approaches to chemical production. The profession formally began with George E. Davis's Handbook of Chemical Engineering (1901) and the first chemical engineering degree programs. The early 1900s saw the development of unit operations concept (Arthur D. Little, 1915), establishing systematic approaches to process design. The 1920s-30s brought petroleum refining advances, catalytic cracking, and polymer chemistry development. The 1940s-50s witnessed petrochemical industry expansion, synthetic materials production, and the introduction of process control systems. The 1960s-70s advanced with computer-aided process design, reaction engineering theory, and environmental regulations driving cleaner processes. The 1980s-90s introduced process simulation software (Aspen Plus), biotechnology applications, and green chemistry principles. The 2000s brought process intensification, nanotechnology integration, and pharmaceutical manufacturing innovations. The 2010s-2020s continue with sustainable chemistry, carbon capture technologies, biorefining, advanced materials synthesis, and AI-optimized process control becoming standard practice.

timeline
    title: The History of Chemical Engineering
    section: 19th Century - The Birth of a Discipline
        1888: George E. Davis teaches the first chemical engineering course at the University of Manchester
        1888: The term "chemical engineering" is coined
    section: Early 20th Century - Unit Operations
        1915: Arthur D. Little introduces the concept of "unit operations"
        1922: The American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) is founded
    section: Mid-20th Century - The Second Paradigm
        1950s: Development of transport phenomena
        1960s: "Bird, Stewart, and Lightfoot" textbook is published
    section: Late 20th Century - The Third Paradigm
        1970s: Rise of process control and systems engineering
        1980s: Development of process simulation software (e.g., Aspen)
    section: The 21st Century - The Fourth Paradigm
        1990s: Rise of biochemical and biomedical engineering
        2000s: Focus on sustainability, green chemistry, and nanotechnology
